::: {.g-col-9 .abstract-section}
## Abstract
This living meta-analysis investigates the relationship between intranasal oxytocin administration and hugging behavior in healthy adults. Current evidence suggests a complex relationship between oxytocin and physical touch-seeking behavior, with mixed results across 42 studies (N = 3,876).
## Current Results
Our latest analysis (k = 42) indicates a small-to-moderate effect of intranasal oxytocin on hugging behavior (Hedges' g = 0.34, 95% CI [0.21, 0.47], p < .001). Significant moderators include:
- Administration timing (β = 0.28, p = .015)
- Social context (β = 0.42, p < .001)
- Previous relationship status (β = 0.31, p = .008)
![Forest plot of effect sizes across studies](https://fake-image-url.com/forest-plot.png)

::: {.g-col-9 .inclusion.exclusion-section}
## Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria
### Inclusion Criteria
- **Participants:** Healthy adults (18-65 years)
- **Intervention:** Intranasal oxytocin administration (single dose 24-40 IU)
- **Comparator:** Placebo-controlled 
- **Outcomes:** Standardized measures of prosocial behavior or trust
- **Study Design:** Randomized controlled trials with between-subjects design
- **Publication Type:** Peer-reviewed articles and preprints
- **Language:** Any language with English abstract
### Exclusion Criteria
- Studies with clinical populations (psychiatric or neurological disorders)
- Animal studies
- Studies using endogenous oxytocin measurement only
- Case studies and non-experimental designs
- Studies without available effect size data or sufficient information to calculate effect sizes
:::
